resources.string: If you have any comments, questions, complaints please send an email to: codelemma@gmail.com.
We will answer you back as soon as we can.\n\nPlease, rate FinanceSim in GooglePlay.

FinanceSim takes income, expenses, savings, and debts as input and gives a simulation output (cash flow, net worth, growth and interrelation of your assets and liabilities) in charts and tables. By playing with input data you can view different scenarios of your financial future.
Constant inflation, constant return from 401(k) and other investments or savings account, and constant tax rate.
FinanceSim is not an expense, income or debt tracker. It uses the data you may track elsewhere, though, as input for the simulations.
I\'ll be happy to hear from you at: codelemma@gmail.com

FinanceSim serves informative functions only and may not be used as a replacement of legal advice. Although every precaution has been taken in preparation of the app, the author assumes no responsibility for errors or omissions and the app is provided without any guarantees, conditions or warranties as to its accuracy.
%s chart empty.\n\n No %s data has yet been added.
%s table empty.\n\n No %s data has yet been added.
Here no input is necessary. All your income, expenses, savings, and debts will be accounted for automatically.
Cashflow chart and table depict monthly inflow and outflow of your capital.
Here no input is necessary. All your income, expenses, savings, and debts will be accounted for automatically.
Net worth chart and table depict your accumulated savings, total debt, and their difference.
Monthly expenses, travel, insurance, rent, etc.
Here add any regular source of income (eg. salary, returns from renting a flat, dividends, etc.).
Rise per year\nEstimated yearly payment increase rate.

Start date\nDate of income commencement. For current salary, specify current month and year. The is independent from simulation start date, which is identical for all your instruments and can be set in Settings.
Income term\nNumber of years to gather income.
Monthly extra payment\nAmount added to your monthly payment.
Start date\nDate of loan commencement. The is independent from simulation start date, which is identical for all your instruments and can be set in Settings.
Down payment\nAmount paid in cash at the onset of the loan.
Mortgage term\nThe length of time the mortgage terms and conditions (including interest rate) are in effect.
Property insurance\nAnnual insurance against risks to the property.

PMI\nPrivate Mortgage Insurance, paid to the lender if the down payment is lower than 20% of the purchased property price or when the loan-to-value ratio is lower than 80 percent. Loan-to-value ratio is a ratio of the loan to the value of an asset purchased.
Start date\nDate of loan commencement. The is independent from simulation start date, which is identical for all your instruments and can be set in Settings.
Inflation rate\nEstimated mean yearly rate of inflation.
Frequency of expense\nNumber of times per year the expense is made.
Start date\nDate the expense starts to be made. The is independent from simulation start date, which is identical for all your instruments and can be set in Settings.
Current amount\nCurrent balance on your account.
Tax rate\nTax rate on the interest. Usually it is taxed at the same rate as wages.

Excess fraction
What percentage of your total monthly excess money (i.e. capital and non-capital income minus expenses, debt rates, and retirement plan deposits) you want to put into the savings account. 

If excess fraction is set to 0%%, no deposits to Savings account will be made and the balance will grow only due to interest rate. 

If excess fraction is more than 0%%, this fraction of the excess money will be saved to the Savings account and the rest will be kept in Checking account. For example, if you have a Savings account with 30%% excess fraction, 30%% of the excess money will be saved to Savings account. All the rest will be kept in Checking account (unless you have other Savings accounts with non-zero excess fraction). 

If excess fraction is 100%%, all the excess money is saved in the Savings account. 

You may have many Saving accounts but their total excess fraction may not be higher than 100%%. For example, you may have Savings account A with 30%% excess fraction, and a Savings account B with 40%% excess fraction. This means that altogether 70%% of your excess money is saved for the Savings account. This money will not be used then for servicing debts and other spendings if income does not cover them.
Current amount\nCurrent balance on your account.
Tax rate\nTax rate on the interest. Usually it is taxed at the same rate as wages.
Current balance\nCurrent balance on your 401(k) account.
Salary\nSalary account associated with the 401(k) plan.
Your contribution\nYour annual contribution rate to the account.
Employer match\nYour employer\'s contribution match rate.
Tax rate at withdrawal\nEstimated tax rate at withdrawal.
Expected return (per year)\nExpected rate of return from the invested 401(k) earnings.

Start date\nDate of 401(k) plan commencement (has to start not earlier than the salary start date). The is independent from simulation start date, which is identical for all your instruments and can be set in Settings.
modify your input data to change these simulation results.
Here input and update your regular income sources (salary, income from renting an apartment, dividends, etc.)
The chart shows monthly net and gross income.
The table shows monthly net income, gross income and tax. If 401(k) is associated with a given income account, the 401(k) contribution is subtracted from the account before tax.

Here input and update your regular expenses, such as monthly spendings, insurance, house or apartment rent, yearly travel budget, etc. \n\nThe submitted amounts are used as starting points in projecting your future expenses with inflation taken into account. Inflation is assumed to be constant over years.
The chart shows the projection of your monthly expenses over years. The rise or fall of the expenses is due to inflation.
Each month the expenses you incur rise (or fall) due to inflation.

Here input and update your bank and retirement plan accounts data. 

Checking account
It is a fixed account used in FinanceSim to deposit all of the remaining monthly income (capital and non-capital) after it has been partitioned into expenses, savings accounts, 401(k) accounts, and debt rates. The interests are compounded continuously and paid monthly. 

Savings account
In a savings account you can store a given percentage of your excess money (i.e. the money remaining after it has been partitioned into expenses, 401(k) accounts, and debt rates). The interests are compounded continuously and paid monthly. 

401(k) account
It is a pension plan common in the US. Contributions to the 401(k) account plan are made on a pre-tax basis so the earnings are tax-deferred. Tax is subtracted from the 401(k) earnings on withdrawal and deposited in the checking account.
The chart shows a projection of your account balance over years.

Checking and savings account

Deposit
Amount of money added monthly to the account. For a savings account it is a percentage (specified by the user) of the so-called excess money, which is the amount left after expenses, debts and retirement plans served. For a checking account it is the money that remain after expenses, debts, retirement contributions, and savings are made. 

Total
Cumulative amount of money stored in an account.

401(k)

Employee and Employer contrib
Monthly contributions to the account from you and your employer.

Loan
This is the most typical loan payment type (a fully amortizing payment), in which each monthly rate has the same value over time. Interests are compounded monthly. 

Mortgage
This is a fixed rate mortgage, which has a fixed interest rate through the entire term of the loan. As a result payment amounts and the duration of the loan are fixed. It also assumes the typical case in which PMI (Private Mortgage Insurance) is paid until loan-to-value ratio reaches 80%. Interests are compounded monthly.

Total interest
Cumulative interests paid up to a given point in time. 

Outstanding loan
The part of the amount borrowed which remains unpaid (exluding interest).

Loan 

Principal
The part of loan paid monthly. 

Interest
The part of the loan fee paid monthly. 

To calculate total monthly payment add principal and interest. 

Total interest
Cumulative amount of interests paid up to a given point in time. 

Remaining amount
The loan amount which remains unpaid (exluding interest).

Mortgage 

Principal
The part of loan paid monthly. 

Interest
The part of the loan fee paid monthly. 

Tax, PMI, insurance
Extra costs, i.e. property tax, Private Mortgage Insurance, and property insurance, paid monthly. 

To calculate total monthly payment add principal, interest, and extra costs. 

Total interest
Cumulative amount of interest paid up to a given point in time. 

Remaining amount
The loan amount which remains unpaid (exluding interest).
Cashflows \nThe cashflows show the projections of your monthly budget breakdown into earings, spendings, and money deposited as savings.

Net income
The sum of all your net income sources in a given month. 

Interest
The sum of the interests and earnings made in a given month, excluding 401(k) earnings (which are deposited in a lump sum to the Checking account at withdrawal). 

Total expenses
The sum of all the spendings made in a given month. 

Debt service
The sum of your monthly debt payments. 

Saved
The amount of money put away into bank accounts (checking, savings, etc.) in a given month. 401(k) earnings are deposited to Checking account in a lump sum at withdrawal..

Net income
The sum of all your net income sources in a given month. 

Interest
The sum of the interests and earnings made in a given month, excluding 401(k) earnings (which are deposited in a lump sum to the Checking account at withdrawal). 

Total expenses
The sum of all the spendings made in a given month. 

Debt service
The sum of your monthly debt payments. 

Saved
The amount of money put away into bank accounts (checking, savings, etc.) in a given month. 401(k) earnings are deposited to Checking account in a lump sum at withdrawal. 

The total of all these amounts (ie. net income + interest - total expenses - debt service - saved) in a given month should be 0, except for the case when you have a Savings account with a non-zero excess fraction and your income do not cover expenses and debts. See Savings / Add savings account / HELP.
Net worth \nNet worth shows the projections of the total of your accumulated assets minus the value of your liabilities.

Savings
The sum of money accumulated. It includes 401(k) savings, while the tax on the 401(k) earnings is subtracted from the savings at 401(k) withdrawal time. 

Outstanding debts
The total of all your debts at a given point in time. 

Net worth
Net worth = savings - debts.
FinanceSim projects your future financial situation based on your current earnings and spendings.\n
enter or modify input data (income, expenses, savings, debts)
\nPlease, rate the app in Google Play.
To add a 401(k) account, please add income data first.
You may add multiple income data.
You may add multiple expense data.
You may add multiple savings data.
You may add multiple debts data.
Error: Total excess fraction higher than 100%
Total excess fraction from all your Savings accounts cannot be higher than 100%%. Please set excess fraction to %s or lower. See HELP for more information.
